Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor's task must be completed before upper management’s evaluation tomorrow.
Situation2: Savings are set aside and friends are going this season.
Story: I sat at my desk, staring at the email from my mentor. The task was clear: finish the project tonight, so it could be reviewed before upper management’s evaluation tomorrow. My mentor had always emphasized responsibility and reliability, and I didn’t want to let them down. But as I glanced at my phone, a message from my friends flashed across the screen—reminding me that this year’s Hajj group was finalizing their plans. I had saved for years, setting aside money with the intention of fulfilling this pillar of my faith. My heart ached at the thought of missing this chance, especially since my friends were going and the timing felt right. Yet, the project demanded my full attention, and I knew my mentor was counting on me. The weight of both expectations pressed on my chest—one calling me to professional duty, the other to spiritual fulfillment. I felt torn, anxiety rising as I tried to imagine how I could possibly honor both commitments.
